Posts.Content: Hi All, I found some interesting facts this past week, and thought that I would pass them along.I was Dx'd last Feb. with stage 3 breast cancer. I went through the Chemo & the Rads treatment, and hopefully everything is well. Last year, a month before we got the news about the cancer, my hubby lost his job after 11 years, so there went our Anthem Blue Cross Insurance. And being we were signing up for unemployment, we could no way afford the Cobra plan. My friend told me about the BCCP program, and I applied and got accepted. When the biopsy came back, and stated that I had Cancer, the BCCP put me on their Medicaid program. They did pay for the Chemo & Rads treatment. But... The canceled me right after.... they told me, being I wasn't doing " Cancer treatment " anymore, I was off the program. They also said that being my Rads Dr. Suspended treatment due to side effects, that was cause to be cut from the program. ( Which he suspended for a week, due to the fact I had Shingles) But I finished every last one of them. :) Now... Here is the interesting part.... What about the " after care"? Well, to make a long battle short. to all you women out there from Ohio.... The BCCP/ Medicaid program, is supposed to cover post treatment. It is up to your Dr. to advise them of this. I found this out, when I contacted Liz Schulte, from the Northern Ohio Breast Cancer Coalition. Her address is as follows, for all of you, that are worried on how you're going to pay the medical bills. Elizabeth Schulte Northern Ohio Breast Cancer Coalition Fund National Breast Cancer Coalition 8921 Brecksville Rd. Brecksville, OH 44141 p - 440-717-9912 f-440-717-9962 www.nobcc.org Northern Ohio Breast Cancer Coalition Fund, a member of the National Breast Cancer Coalition, is a non-profit, 501 c 3 group that engages in advocacy on behalf of and provides assistance to those living with breast cancer. NOBCC is a group of Ohio breast cancer survivors and their allies dedicated to eradicating breast cancer through grassroots advocacy and education. Formed in 2000, the group is working to change the world of breast cancer by improving breast cancer public policy and expanding the influence of breast cancer survivors in all aspects of the breast cancer decision making process.
Posts.Title: Ohio Bccp/medicaid For Un-insured & Under-insured

Posts.Content: On 11/14/2008 nlc145 wrote: My mother called me last tuesday and said she had a mammogram and the doctor said he found something. she supposedly went in wed. for a biopsy. monday she sent a message that it was cancer. then this wednesday it had spread to the lymphnodes and today she said it was terminal. she said the doctor offered no treatment and no other options. she has a history of mental illness and often acts out for attention. i am just wondering if this timeline is possible. also if it is true would a doctor call on the phone and give the news and then offer no treatment at all. please help!!! i am concerned and feel very lost. Hello,  I am sorry to read about your mom. As for the time, relating to everything that has happened to her.. I can only tell, you about my experience.  I went in for a mammogram, on a Monday. The nurse told me to sit tight for a moment, and the the Dr. appeared. And told me he thought I had breast cancer. And in the meantime, he called my family Dr. And made an appt. for me , for that same afternon.  My family Dr. Then went and made an appt. with the surgeon. I went to see the surgeon, on a Weds. And was in surgery that Friday.  That was 4 years ago, they did a lumpectomy at that time. I was Dx'd with Stage 3 Breast cancer. A year a half ago, I was Dx'd with Stage1 cancer in the other breast, and opted for the bi-lateral mastectomy. Have a great weekend!    So.. It is possible, to have a DX. that soon.
Posts.Title: I want to verify cancer diagnosis

Posts.Content: Hi Everyone!  I had a double mastectomy a year & a half ago. And opted not to have the reconstruction. Has anyone had a problem, with the bras riding up, and settling on the incision?  I have an open wound ( Yes, after 1 1/2 years) But anyway, that's a story in it's self.   I am looking for a way, or a garment, that won't ride up on the incision.  I have tried the cammy's and that is ok.. But for something more formal, does anyone have any ideas? I have the sylicone(?) forms, and the softies as well. Any advice would be greatly appreciated. Regards,  Deb
Posts.Title: Mastectomy Apparel

Posts.Content: On 9/12/2009 marcia63 wrote: Yes, I took Taxotere three years ago.  I had Stage II breast cancer six years ago and it recurred three years later.  The second time I had a mastectomy, Taxotere (4 times - once every 3 weeks) and Herceptin for a year (I was HER2 positive).  The cancer had spread to my lung and I also had a thoracotomy where they removed the spot from my lung.  Taxotere is made to work more directly on cancer cells and doesn't interefere quite as much with healthy cells.  Taxol is its counterpart.  I lost a little bit of hair on Taxotere, but not all of it - I did not need a wig like I did with Adriamycin and Cytoxin.  Taxotere had very few side effects.  That was three years ago and I am still in remission.  I think it is a good drug and if she has had other chemos in the past, she'll think this one is quite mild, even though it is a very strong drug. Hope all goes well. Marcia Hi Marcia,  I have to agree with you. I was Dx'd in 2005 with Stage 3 breast Cancer. Then had it agaIN IN 2007.  The Taxotere was alot better to side effect wise than the A/C was.
Posts.Title: Anyone heard of the drug Taxotere?

Posts.Content: Wayne, Thanks for the info on the Green Tea! I used to take it years ago, and I guess , I'll go back on it! And add it to my " collection" of herbs & vitamins to take! I went to my Oncologist last month, and he told me, that whatever I was doing, to keep doing it, 'cause everything came back fine. Since I wrote my last note, I have been job hunting,That was a real trip! I went for an interview at a local private club, for a bartending job,( being I used to work at the local country club years ago I felt, WOW I could do this ... no problem! lol Well, damn, after I walked in there and seen the other " girls" with hip huggers and belly button rings, I sure felt like an ANTIQUE! LOL But while I was going through Rads, I was also going taking classes, and finally landed a job, in a local nursing home. They say that things come " full circle" Well, this did, it was the nursing home that I worked at 30 years ago! when I was in my early 20's. I talked to there DON and was telling her that next year I wanted to go back and get my RN degree. She told me that when I decided to do that , to let her know, and she would tutor me, before the entrance exam. So.... to everyone out there, there is hope at the end of the tunnel. Sometimes you have to step back, and take a look at where you are going. And I believe there are angles that guild us through life. Please don't think, that I am "little Miss Postitve Attitude" because there were times, that I would just sit and cry. We were your normal, middle aged couple, we raised our 2 boys, and they are out on there own, and were were looking forward to " our time" And then all hell broke loose. Hubby lost his job, after 20 years, in Jan. And I was diagnosed with Breast Cancer later that month. Needless to say, it was a roller coaster ride, that we will never forget. But.... Things are finally starting to fall back into place. yes, I did lose my business, but I also had a lot of time to think about things. What I have learned is that,God, and good friends will always pull you through. As my one girlfriend told me. " if God brought you to it, he'll pull you through it" And that's exactly what he did. Regards, Breeze
Posts.Title: Does Anyone Else Wonder What To Do Now That The Treatments Are Over?

Posts.Title: Does Anyone Else Wonder What To Do Now That The Treatments Are Over?

Posts.Content: This letter is in response to Wayne. O have heard that Green Tea, will help. I have been taking the Essaic's Tea, since I was in radiation. ( I was diagnosed with stage 3 B.C. on Feb.) 2 weeks ago, I had another biopsy, and it came just fine. weather it was the essiac's Tea, or prayer... i am not really sure! But i do believe in both! :) As far as coping after treatment. it's hard to stay positive. I am 49 years old, lost my business, due to scheduling for chemo & rads treatemnt. and trying to start all over at 49 is a real treat!! LOL.... not to mention, trying to get life insurance! I got refused coverage from one of the major companys in the U.S. Even though right now I am cancer free. Just the " label" As having had Cancer is a problem. I like many others wonder.... what the hell , do I do now?? But i keep plugging along.... Best regards, to everyone that is in the samne boat
Posts.Title: Does Anyone Else Wonder What To Do Now That The Treatments Are Over?

Posts.Content: On 5/17/2009 lillemor wrote: Just finished my 3rd try at estrogen feeding tumor and I'm done with the pills!! My shoulders froze,could not bend or use my arms or wrists. Just 3 hrs. of being taken off Feemara and put on Prednisone, I could bend my arms, my head had cleared.  I did not realize how dangerous I was thinking. My husband was amazed. I could not go to the bathroom , take a shower without much help. Towards the end my husband lifted from bed and had to feed me. This is not Life and it is a poor form of existence. I am now eating maitake mushrooms almost daily and am going to look into the Coriolus Versicolan extract.  It has been proven that the maitake mushroom kills the cancer cells. I have been on Aromasin,Tamoxifen and Feemara. lillemor I wish you the best,  on the choice that you made. It is a very personal choice.:) ( I made the same choice you did 5 years ago, and have not regretted it). Also, you might be interested in the Essiacs Tea.
Posts.Title: Done with drugs
